results.title: The Golden age of the automobile
results.creator_credit: Helen Jean Secondari and John H. Secondari
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the automobile from its early years as a plaything of the rich, through Henry Ford’s development of the Model T for the average worker, to the present day when its proliferation has altered the face of the western world. Suitable for upper primary and secondary level.

results.title: The Golden age of steam: locomotives
results.brief_description: Remember the days of the steam-train and the wonderful sound of the locomotive engine? Then this documentary will take you back in history, to the “golden age of steam”. Produced and filmed in Britain, and containing some rare archival footage, the program presents an historical look at the steam locomotive, including the replica (built in the 1970s) of George Stephenson’s “Rocket”. Also shows examples of such well-known company names as Fenchurch, Stowe, Wainwright and Pennine Ltd which are still running today. Photographed in some of Britain’s beautiful countryside, these locomotives are seen winding through small villages, climbing up steep grades and passing through busy stations. One of the best attributes of the documentary is that it contains minimal commentary allowing the viewer to experience the sound and atmosphere of a bygone era.

results.title: The Golden age of Flemish art
results.creator_credit: Paul Haesaerts, Jean Van Raemdonck and Art et Cinema
results.brief_description: The Golden age of Flemish art explores the meanings, beauties and quaint anecdotal material hidden in the incredibly detailed paintings of Flemish “primitives”. The film displays and comments upon works by Jan Van Eyck, Roger van der Weyden, Dirk Bouts, Hans Memling, Hugo van der Goes, Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel, and Quentin Metsus.

results.title: The Golden age of comedy
results.brief_description: This inspired madness makes the impossible possible by assembling the greatest cast of comedians that ever lived. This film contains the first comedians in their funniest sketches. Compiled from over 2,000 reels, “The Golden Age of Comedy” is a montage of outrageous slapstick humour that marked the highest point in film comedy. It remains a milestone in hilarious amusement and is without doubt the most memorable collection of classic comedy sketches. A must for those who enjoy sidesplitting entertainment. Rated: G

results.title: The Gold rush. - Edited version
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin, Dennis R. Atkinson and Spectra Films
results.brief_description: An abridged version of Charlie Chaplin’s 1925 silent film classic, with commentary and a music track added. Deals with the hardships of life on the Alaskan frontier. Suitable for film studies students.

results.title: The Gold Rush (1925)
results.brief_description: The Gold Rush, an immortal classic, is regarded as one of Chaplin’s very best films, interweaving to brilliant effect the pathetic tale of the Tramp’s apparently hopeless love for a dancehall girl with the funny story of the Tramp and his burly gold prospecting partner heading off to make their fortunes in the great Yukon gold rush. Through the entire film hangs Chaplin’s finely perceived view of the contrast between the Tramp’s selfless, humanitarian behaviour, and the unpleasant, brutish life of the gold town society. Rated: G

results.title: The Gold rush
results.brief_description: A revival of the original silent Chaplin comedy with narrative and descriptive dialogue added about a lone prospector who ventures into Alaska for gold. He meets up with some unsavoury characters and falls in love with the beautiful Georgia. Cast includes Mack Swain, Georgia Hale, Tom Murray and Henry Bergman. The narrative was written and spoken by Charles Chaplin.

results.title: The Gold ghost
results.creator_credit: Charles Lamont, Buster Keaton, E Allen and Educational Films Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Dumped by his girlfriend, Buster drives west and winds up in a ghost town called Vulture City, where he appoints himself sheriff. Also stars Dorothy Dix, William Worthington and Lloyd Ingraham. Written by Ewart Adamson and Nicholas T. Barrows.

results.title: The Gold diggers
results.brief_description: A humorous dramatisation of the ballad about two diggers in search of gold. They are frustrated by bad weather, the lure of the ‘grog’, hard rock, costly water and finally…no gold! The words were written on the Victorian goldfields in the 1850s.
